title: Framework Computer
content:

[[File:Framework laptop part made with love by team.jpg|thumb|Framework team member's names printed on a part of the Framework Laptop.]]

'''Framework Computer Inc''', commonly referred to as '''Framework''', is an American laptop manufacturer.<ref name="pcmag">{{Cite web|first1=Matthew|last1=Buzzi|first2=John|last2=Burek|url=https://www.pcmag.com/reviews/framework-laptop|title=Framework Laptop Review|date=August 25, 2021|website=PCMAG}}</ref><ref name="tomsguide">{{Cite web|url=https://www.tomsguide.com/reviews/framework-laptop-review-the-anti-macbook-has-arrived|title=Framework Laptop review: The anti-MacBook has arrived|first=Alex|last=Wawro|date=August 18, 2021|website=Tom's Guide}}</ref><ref name="arstechnica">{{Cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2021/07/frameworks-new-lightweight-modular-laptop-delivers-on-its-promises/|title=Review: Framework's lightweight modular laptop is a winner|first=Jim|last=Salter|date=July 27, 2021|website=Ars Technica}}</ref><ref name="cnet">{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnet.com/tech/computing/framework-laptop-review-a-functional-and-futureproof-13-inches/|title=Framework Laptop review: A functional and futureproof 13 inches|first=Lori|last=Grunin|date=July 22, 2021|website=CNET}}</ref> The company positions itself as a proponent of the [[electronics right to repair]] movement,<ref name="ft">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/e1e6d16c-4e0b-45a9-8007-95da916341f0|title=Why Big Tech should embrace the 'right to repair' revolution|website=www.ft.com|first1=Dave|last1=Lee|date=August 31, 2021}}</ref><ref name="freethink">{{Cite web|url=https://www.freethink.com/series/challengers/right-to-repair|title=This DIY laptop is challenging tech giants like Apple & Microsoft|website=www.freethink.com|author=Freethink Team|date=October 16, 2021}}</ref><ref name="makezine"/> and their laptops are designed to be easy to disassemble, with replaceable parts.<ref name="pcmag"/><ref name="tomsguide"/> The company's approach has earned them praise from [[Louis Rossmann]],<ref name="LouisRossmann">{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G2YjKYG8P58|title=Frame.work isn't virtue signalling; they genuinely support Right to Repair. I wish them success.|first1=Louis|last1=Rossmann|date=July 23, 2021|via=www.youtube.com}}</ref><ref name="LouisRossmann-schematics">{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8cJj8PUY0DU|title=Framework laptop finally embraces "schematics or die", long live framework!|first1=Louis|last1=Rossmann|date=May 13, 2022|via=www.youtube.com}}</ref> [[Linus Sebastian]],<ref name="linus-tech-tips-review">{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0rkTgPt3M4k|title=A Completely Upgradeable Laptop? - Framework Laptop Review|author=Linus Tech Tips|date=July 26, 2021|via=www.youtube.com}}</ref> the latter having invested $225,000 into the company,<ref name="linus-tech-tips-disclose">{{Cite web|publisher=Linus Tech Tips|title=I'm Legally Obligated to Disclose This|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LSxbc1IN9Gg|date=September 15, 2021|via=www.youtube.com|url-status=live}}</ref> and [[Cory Doctorow]].<ref name="CoryDoctorow-2021">{{Cite web|url=https://pluralistic.net/2021/09/21/monica-byrne/#think-different|title=The Framework is the most exciting laptop I’ve ever used|first1=Cory|last1=Doctorow|date=September 21, 2021|website=pluralistic.net}}</ref><ref name="CoryDoctorow-2022">{{Cite web|url=https://pluralistic.net/2022/11/13/graceful-failure/#frame|title=The Framework is the most exciting laptop I've ever broken|first1=Cory|last1=Doctorow|date=November 13, 2022|website=pluralistic.net}}</ref> In November 2021, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine listed the Framework Laptop on their list of the 100 Best Inventions of 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://time.com/collection/best-inventions-2021/6112625/framework-laptop/|title=A Notebook You Can Repair: Framework Laptop|first=Don|last=Steinberg|date=November 10, 2021|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]}}</ref> ''[[Fast Company]]'' listed the Framework Laptop on their list of the Most Innovative Companies of 2022.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/90722815/framework-innovative-laptop-easy-repair-electronics|title=How Framework is helping fix our unsustainable electronics industry|first=Jared|last=Newman|date=March 8, 2022|work=[[Fast Company]]}}</ref>

== History ==

In January 2020, the company was founded by Nirav Patel who was the head of hardware at [[Reality Labs|Oculus]].<ref name="makezine" /><ref name="freethink" /> In the first half 2021, the company was funded with a $9 million [[seed money|seed round]].<ref name="framework-pitch-series-a">{{Cite web|url=https://pitch.com/presentations/Framework-Pitch-Deck-3mETzR4VNkQP5ncnEk0eS8Kk?slide=472d36fd-f50e-49d2-9b4d-a0396debadf8|title=Framework Pitch Deck by @framework - Pitch|publisher=Framework|date=May 24, 2022|website=Pitch}}</ref><ref name="anorak-post">{{Cite web|url=https://www.anorak.vc/post/why-i-invested-in-framework|title=Why I invested in Framework|first=Greg|last=Castle|date=Jun 21, 2021|website=Anorak Ventures}}</ref> In January 2022, the company was funded with an $18 million [[series A round|series A]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://frame.work/blog/frameworks-series-a-and-the-years-ahead|title=Framework’s Series A and the Years Ahead|date=January 27, 2022|author=Nirav Patel|website=frame.work}}</ref><ref name="techcrunch-series-a">{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2022/02/01/framework-looks-to-expand-repairability-beyond-the-laptop/|title=Framework looks to expand repairability beyond the laptop|date=February 1, 2022|website=TechCrunch}}</ref> The company shared their [[series A round|series A]] [[pitch book|pitch deck]] with reducted parts.<ref name="framework-pitch-series-a" />

==Products==

For the products repairability and upgradability, the company's website provides guides for the replacement and repair<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://guides.frame.work/|title=Framework Guides|website=frame.work}}</ref> and the marketplace.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://frame.work/marketplace|title=Fix Consumer Electronics|website=frame.work}}</ref>

=== Framework Laptop ===

[[File:Framework laptop sway community forum small.png|thumb|Framework Laptop]]
In July 2021, Framework started to ship their first product Framework Laptop with an 11th Gen Intel Core i5 or i7 chip to the [[United States|US]] and [[Canada]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://frame.work/blog/the-framework-laptop-is-now-shipping-and-press-reviews|title=The Framework Laptop is now shipping, and press reviews are up!|author=Nirav Patel|website=frame.work}}</ref> In December 2021, Framework opened pre-orders to the [[United Kingdom|UK]], [[Germany]] and [[France]].<ref name="frame.work-pre-order-uk-germany-france">{{Cite web|date=December 16, 2021|url=https://frame.work/blog/now-available-for-pre-order-in-uk-germany-and-france|title=Now Available for Pre-order in UK, Germany, and France|author=Nirav Patel|website=frame.work}}</ref> In February 2022, pre-ordering became available for [[Ireland]], [[Austria]] and [[Netherlands|The Netherlands]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last=Patel|first=Nirav|date=2022-02-22|title=Bringing the Framework Laptop to more of the world|url=https://frame.work/nl/en/blog/bringing-the-framework-laptop-to-more-of-the-world|access-date=2022-02-23|website=Framework|language=en}}</ref> The Framework Laptop received a 10 out of 10 in [[iFixit|iFixit's]] repairability score.<ref>{{Cite web|date=July 28, 2021|title=Framework Laptop Teardown: 10/10, But is it Perfect?|url=https://www.ifixit.com/News/51614/framework-laptop-teardown-10-10-but-is-it-perfect|website=iFixit|language=en}}</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2022/apr/13/framework-laptop-review-a-modular-pc-easy-to-fix-or-upgrade Framework Laptop review: a modular PC easy to fix or upgrade] The Guardian. 2022.</ref> The standard Framework Laptop ships as a fully assembled laptop, while the Framework Laptop [[Do_it_yourself|DIY]] Edition ships with the RAM, storage, operating system, and in 11th Gen, the WiFi module uninstalled. All of these modules can be ordered with the DIY edition, or left out and purchased separately.

In May 2022, the company launched their second generation Framework Laptop with a 12th Gen Intel Core i5 or i7 chip that ships with an upgraded back panel, alongside their 12 Gen Upgrade Kit, to allow 11th Gen users to upgrade their laptops. In September 2022, pre-ordering became available for [[Australia]]. <ref>{{Cite web |title=Now available for pre-order in Australia |url=https://frame.work/blog/now-available-for-pre-order-in-australia |access-date=2022-09-11 |website=Framework |language=en}}</ref>

In September 2022, the company started to pre-order the Framework Laptop [[Chromebook]] Edition to the [[United States|US]] and [[Canada]].<ref name="framework-chromebook">{{Cite web|date=September 21, 2022|url=https://frame.work/blog/introducing-the-framework-laptop-chromebook-edition|title=Introducing the Framework Laptop Chromebook Edition|author=Marissa Buyck|website=frame.work}}</ref><ref name="google-framework-chromebook">{{Cite web|date=September 21, 2022|url=https://blog.google/products/chromebooks/built-for-sustainability/|title=New Chromebooks built with sustainability in mind|first=Racha|last=Slaoui|website=blog.google}}</ref><ref name="chromeunboxed-framework-chromebook">{{Cite web|url=https://chromeunboxed.com/framework-laptop-chromebook-edition-google-chrome-os/|title=Google and Framework partner up to launch a fully-modular Chromebook|first=Robby|last=Payne|date=September 21, 2022|website=Chrome Unboxed}}</ref><ref name="zdnet-chromebook">{{Cite web|url=https://www.zdnet.com/article/frameworks-new-chromebook-laptop-pieces-together-the-best-of-both-worlds/|title=Framework's new Chromebook laptop pieces together the best of both worlds|first=June|last=Wan|date=September 21, 2022|website=ZDNET}}</ref>

==== Mainboard ====

In April 2022, the company partly open sourced their [[motherboard|mainboard]] with [[Computer-aided design|CAD]] and electrical documentation,<ref>{{Cite web|date=April 18, 2022|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rjUlznKioo&t=300s|title=The Download: New Job, New Channel, DALL-E 2, Framework Laptop and more|author=GitHub|via=www.youtube.com}}</ref><ref name="arstechnica-mainboard">{{Cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2022/04/framework-will-sell-you-its-laptop-motherboard-without-the-laptop-for-399/|title=Buy the Framework laptop’s $399 motherboard to make your own mini PC|first=Andrew|last=Cunningham|date=April 22, 2022|website=Ars Technica}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=May 1, 2022|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u1B1ooz5aSU|title=The Framework Mainboard Case! Printed, Built, Tested.|author=Elevated Systems|via=www.youtube.com}}</ref><ref name="LouisRossmann-schematics" /> being available in their [[marketplace]], giving away 100 mainboards to makers and developers.<ref name="frame.work-mainboard">{{Cite web|date=April 18, 2022|url=https://frame.work/blog/mainboard-availability-and-open-source-release|title=Mainboard Availability and Open Source Release|author=Nirav Patel|website=frame.work}}</ref><ref name="hackaday-mainboard">{{Cite web|url=https://hackaday.com/2022/04/21/modular-laptop-maker-provides-mainboard-documentation-for-non-laptop-projects/|title=Modular Laptop Maker Provides Mainboard Documentation For Non-Laptop Projects|first=Ryan|last=Flowers|date=April 21, 2022|website=Hackaday}}</ref>

There does appear to be an issue with the first generation mainboard with 11th Gen Intel Core, that requires complete removal and reconnection of both main battery and [[real-time clock|RTC]] coin cell battery, if the laptop is not charged for a relatively short period of time.<ref>{{Cite web|date=June 7, 2022|url=https://community.frame.work/t/laptop-wont-power-on-unless-i-plug-in-ac-power/13085/61|title=Laptop won’t power on unless i plug in AC power|website=community.frame.work}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://yeokhengmeng.com/2021/09/review-usage-and-repair-of-the-framework-laptop/|title=Review, usage and repair of the Framework laptop|website=yeokhengmeng.com|author=Yeo Kheng Meng|date=September 21, 2021|access-date=June 19, 2022}}</ref> The company said that the issue is by 11th Gen Intel Core silicon bug, and they would work to swap out a replacement [[real-time clock|RTC]] coin cell battery or 11th Gen mainboard to the people seeing the issue.<ref>{{Cite web|date=June 15, 2022|url=https://community.frame.work/t/rtc-viability-of-using-a-rechargable-rtc-battery/17664/43|title=RTC: Viability of using a rechargable RTC battery|website=community.frame.work}}</ref><ref name="linus-tech-tips-first-generation-rtc-battery">{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U5YOjLdfRZA&t=5958s|title=It's Coming For Us... - WAN Show June 17, 2022 - Framework transparency|author=Linus Tech Tips|date=June 17, 2022|via=www.youtube.com}}</ref>

==== Expansion Cards ====

A core feature of the Framework Laptop is the detachable Expansion Cards that provide the primary input/output for the laptop. The laptop has four expansion slots that can each accept one of seven expansion cards. These consist of USB-C, USB-A, DisplayPort 1.4, HDMI 2.0b, 256GB storage expansion, 1TB storage expansion, and MicroSD.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Fix Consumer Electronics |url=https://frame.work/marketplace/expansion-cards |access-date=2022-08-30 |website=Framework |language=en}}</ref> A 2.5GbE Ethernet expansion card is currently under development. In addition, each expansion slot has a recessed USB-C port, which can both be used to connect expansion cards, or as a standard USB-C port, though connecting a USB-C expansion card allows for easier access to the port. The company launched the Expansion Card Developer Program to open card development, released documentation, [[Computer-aided design|CAD]] templates, and reference designs for Expansion Cards, all under open source licenses to make it easy for both hardware companies and individual makers to create new card designs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/FrameworkComputer/ExpansionCards|title=Reference designs and documentation to create Expansion Cards for the Framework Laptop|via=github.com|author=Framework Computer}}</ref>

==== Firmware ====

The laptop uses a proprietary [[BIOS]] firmware, InsydeH2O [[UEFI]] [[BIOS]] by [[Insyde Software]]<ref>{{Cite web|date=August 9, 2021|url=https://www.insyde.com/press_news/press-releases/insyde%C2%AE-software-powers-newly-launched-framework%E2%84%A2-modular-laptop|title=Insyde® Software Powers Newly Launched Framework™ Modular Laptop|website=Insyde Software}}</ref> and an open sourced [[embedded controller]] (EC) firmware based on CrOS EC<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/platform/ec/+/HEAD/README.md|title=CrOS EC (Embedded Controller)|website=chromium.googlesource.com}}</ref> by Framework. In April 2021, the company mentioned that open source firmware was well aligned to their mission.<ref>{{Cite web|date=April 11, 2021|url=https://community.frame.work/t/free-the-ec-and-coreboot-only/791/5|title=Coreboot on the Framework Laptop|website=community.frame.work|access-date=June 18, 2022}}</ref> In January 2022, the company open sourced their EC firmware.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gamingonlinux.com/2022/01/framework-put-up-the-source-code-for-their-embedded-controller-firmware/|title=Framework put up the source code for their Embedded Controller firmware|first=Liam|last=Dawe|date=January 21, 2022|via=www.gamingonlinux.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=January 21, 2022|url=https://frame.work/blog/open-sourcing-our-firmware|title=Open Sourcing our Firmware|author=Nirav Patel|website=frame.work}}</ref> The company modifies the BIOS source code they bought from [[Insyde Software]] to meet their specific BIOS needs. The company's [[Linux]] Vendor Firmware Service (LVFS) with [[fwupd]] is in testing state.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://fwupd.org/lvfs/devices/work.frame.Laptop.TGL.BIOS.firmware|title=LVFS Framework Laptop TGL|website=fwupd.org|access-date=May 12, 2022}}</ref>

{| class="wikitable"
|+ BIOS firmware on the mainboards
|-
! Mainboard !! BIOS product !! Upstream BIOS vendor !! Initial BIOS version !! Latest BIOS version
|-
| 11th Gen [[Intel Core]] || InsydeH2O UEFI BIOS || [[Insyde Software]] || 3.02 || 3.10<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://knowledgebase.frame.work/framework-laptop-bios-releases-S1dMQt6F|title=Framework Laptop BIOS and Driver Releases (11th Gen Intel® Core™)|website=knowledgebase.frame.work|access-date=October 30, 2022}}</ref>
|-
| 12th Gen [[Intel Core]] || InsydeH2O UEFI BIOS || [[Insyde Software]] || 3.04 || 3.04<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://knowledgebase.frame.work/framework-laptop-bios-and-driver-releases-12th-gen-intel-core-Bkx2kosqq|title=Framework Laptop BIOS and Driver Releases (12th Gen Intel® Core™)|website=knowledgebase.frame.work|access-date=October 30, 2022}}</ref>
|}

==== Marketplace ====

The Framework Marketplace is an online store service hosted on the Framework website that primarily sells parts and tools that can be used to repair the Framework Laptop. These include, but are not limited to, replacement mainboards, audio modules, entire screen assemblies, and additional RAM and storage drives. The Marketplace also sells customization parts, including different colors of screen bezels, different keyboard layouts, and additional expansion cards. Notably, a "Carbon Capture" may be purchased for $100 US that makes "your Framework Laptop carbon neutral by buying one unit of carbon capture and sequestration."<ref>{{Cite web |title=Carbon Capture |url=https://frame.work/products/carbon-capture |access-date=2022-08-30 |website=Framework |language=en}}</ref> This essentially donates money directly to Running Tide, a company that is dedicated to removing carbon emissions from the atmosphere.

==== Battery life ====

The battery life has been described as mediocre.<ref name="arstechnica" /><ref name=elevated-systems-6months-review>{{Cite web|date=February 27, 2022|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fNYZkqIn8rg|title=Framework Laptop 6 Months Later. I'm Less Impressed|author=Elevated Systems|via=www.youtube.com}}</ref> The battery drains in a completely shut down state in [[BIOS]] version 3.07 or earlier with the 11th [[Intel Core]] [[motherboard|mainboard]],<ref>{{Cite web|date=January 18, 2022|url=https://community.frame.work/t/battery-slowly-drains-when-completely-shut-down/13923|title=Battery slowly drains when completely shut down|website=community.frame.work}}</ref> however the BIOS unofficial version 3.08 and later versions fix the issue.<ref name="twitter-framework-20220610">{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/FrameworkPuter/status/1535041802125729792|title=Framework on Twitter|publisher=Framework|date=June 10, 2022|via=twitter.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=April 14, 2022|url=https://community.frame.work/t/is-there-something-wrong-with-the-3-08-bios/17509/|title=Is there something wrong with the 3.08 BIOS?|website=community.frame.work}}</ref>

== Company or individually driven projects ==

[[File:Mainboard-terminal-heroshot.jpg|thumb|Mainboard Terminal, a retro-style round display PC that uses the Framework's [[motherboard|mainboard]] with Ubuntu.]]
[[File:Framedeck framework logo.jpg|thumb|Framedeck, a Framework [[motherboard|mainboard]] based cyberdeck with clear acrylic and brass influenced by [[TRS-80 Model 100]].]]
[[File:Framework Tablet Complete Build.jpg|thumb|Framework-Tablet, a 3D printable tablet case for Framework Laptop.]]

Third party companies and individuals make their projects<ref>{{Cite web|date=May 16, 2022|url=https://community.frame.work/t/a-company-or-individual-driven-projects/18559|title=Company or individually driven projects|website=community.frame.work|access-date=May 17, 2022}}</ref><ref name="gizmodo-mods">{{Cite web|url=https://gizmodo.com/these-framework-laptop-mods-show-us-exactly-why-modular-1848341702|title=These Framework Laptop Mods Show Us Exactly Why Modular Computers Are So Damn Cool|date=January 17, 2022|website=Gizmodo}}</ref> in a Framework [[software ecosystem|ecosystem]].

In December 2022, Framework joined the 3D printing database site, Printables.com<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.printables.com/|title=3D models database - Printables.com|website=www.printables.com}}</ref> as a brand, highlighting the community projects.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2022/12/framework-noctua-and-other-brands-add-official-3d-models-to-printables/|title=Framework, Noctua, and other brands add official 3D models to Printables|first=Kevin|last=Purdy|date=December 20, 2022|website=Ars Technica}}</ref>

=== Decoration ===

* Framework Laptop skins & wraps<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dbrand.com/shop/framework-laptop-skins|title=Framework Laptop Skins & Wraps|website=dbrand.com|author=dbrand}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Rd61cLOEtdA|title=How to Apply a dbrand Framework Laptop Skin|via=www.youtube.com|author=dbrand|date=December 5, 2021}}</ref>
* Screen protector film<ref>{{Cite web|date=July 26, 2021|url=https://community.frame.work/t/matte-screen-protector/2978/|title=Matte screen protector|website=community.frame.work|access-date=October 28, 2022}}</ref>
* Arts & wallpapers<ref>{{Cite web|date=September 12, 2021|url=https://community.frame.work/t/framework-fan-art/6626/|title=Framework Fan Art|website=community.frame.work|access-date=December 27, 2021}}</ref>

=== Parts management ===

* Module frame<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.printables.com/model/231439-framework-laptop-module-frame|title=frame.work laptop module frame |via=www.printables.com|author=egeltje|access-date=December 28, 2022}}</ref>
* Parts tray<ref>{{Cite web|date=August 4, 2022|url=https://community.frame.work/t/framework-parts-tray/20965|title=Framework Parts Tray|website=community.frame.work}}</ref><ref name="frame.work-2022-review">{{Cite web|url=https://frame.work/blog/framework-in-2022-year-in-review|title=Framework in 2022: Year-in-review|date=December 20, 2022|first=Marissa|last=Buyck|website=frame.work}}</ref>

=== Expansion card ===

* Magnetic charger expansion card<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LwPOC8_xUMg|title=Framework Laptop Magnetic Charger Expansion Card Full power!|via=www.youtube.com|date=October 29, 2021}}</ref><ref name="gizmodo-mods" />
* Dual [[USB-C]] expansion card<ref>{{Cite web|date=June 14, 2021|url=https://community.frame.work/t/dual-usb-c-expansion-card-mockup/2325/|title=Dual USB-C Expansion Card Mockup |website=community.frame.work|access-date=October 28, 2022}}</ref>
* [[LTE_(telecommunication)|LTE]] Cat 4 Cell modem expansion card<ref>{{Cite web|date=October 21, 2021|url=https://community.frame.work/t/lte-cat-4-cell-modem-card/9454|title=LTE Cat 4 Cell Modem Card|website=community.frame.work}}</ref>
* Scroll wheels expansion card<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2FCxMRbzfaM|title=roPlug Demonstration|via=www.youtube.com|date=November 4, 2021}}</ref>
* [[Universal asynchronous receiver-transmitter|UART]] expansion card<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6XnrZpPYgBg|title=EEVblog 1496 - Winning Mailbag|publisher=EEVblog|via=www.youtube.com|date=August 26, 2022}}</ref>
* Solokeys<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://solokeys.com/|title=SoloKeys - Built with Trusted|website=solokeys.com}}</ref> Solo V2 expansion card<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/foosinn/Solo4Framework|title=foosinn/Solo4Framework|via=github.com|author=foosinn|access-date=December 28, 2022}}</ref><ref name="frame.work-2022-review" />

==== Hardware using expansion card ====

* Box, a hardware for cloud storage alternative that uses Framework Expansion Cards.<ref>{{Cite web|date=March 1, 2022|url=https://venturebeat.com/2022/03/01/functionland-unveils-groundbreaking-hardware-box-the-web3-solution-to-cloud-subscriptions/|title=Functionland Unveils Groundbreaking Hardware: BOX – The Web3 Solution to Cloud Subscriptions|website=VentureBeat}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thegadgetflow.com/blog/box-by-functionland-provides-private-cloud-storage-blockchain-more/|title=Box by Functionland provides easy-to-use private cloud storage for blockchain and important data|date=Apr 6, 2022|website=Gadget Flow}}</ref>

=== Mainboard based ===

* CJ64, a cyberdeck-like keyboard [[personal computer|PC]] that re-purposes the Framework Laptop's [[motherboard|mainboard]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/CJ-Elevated/Project_CJ64|title=CJ-Elevated/Project_CJ64: The Framework Mainboard Project CJ64 enclosure |via=github.com|author= Elevated Systems|access-date=June 19, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VeYfKu9KlTg|title=Complete PC in a Mechanical Keyboard! Retro Concept, Modern Hardware.|via=www.youtube.com|author=Elevated Systems|date=November 7, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ewVp96JN0nQ|title=The Ultimate Framework Keyboard PC! Machined Aluminum Mainboard Enclosure!|via=www.youtube.com|author=Elevated Systems|date=June 19, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tomshardware.com/news/framework-keyboard-cyberdeck|title=Framework Laptop Mainboard Powers Custom 60% Mechanical Keyboard|date=November 11, 2021|website=Tom's Hardware}}</ref><ref name="gizmodo-mods" />
* Mainboard Terminal, a retro-style round display [[personal computer|PC]] that uses the Framework Laptop's [[motherboard|mainboard]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/penk/MainboardTerminal|title=penk/MainboardTerminal: Mainboard Terminal - A Retro-style Computer with a Modern Core|via=github.com|author=Penk Chen|access-date=May 10, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tomshardware.com/news/framework-mainboard-modular-circular-cyberdeck|title=Sensational Circular-Screened Cyberdeck Hides Modular Intel 11th Gen PC|date=May 10, 2022|website=Tom’s Hardware}}</ref>
* Framedeck, a Framework [[motherboard|mainboard]] based cyberdeck with clear acrylic and brass influenced by [[TRS-80 Model 100]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/brickbots/framedeck|title=brickbots/framedeck: A Framework mainboard based Cyberdeck|via=github.com|author=brickbots, Richard|access-date=May 16, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hackster.io/news/richard-sutherland-s-framedeck-is-a-trs-80-model-100-inspired-open-source-portable-pc-9937a2d73272|title=Richard Sutherland's Framedeck Is a TRS-80 Model 100 Inspired Open Source Portable PC|date=May 16, 2022|website=Hackster.io}}</ref>
* A tablet that uses Framework parts including the [[motherboard|mainboard]].<ref>{{Cite web|date=March 22, 2022|url=https://community.frame.work/t/framework-tablet-project/16690|title=Framework Tablet Project|website=community.frame.work}}</ref> Framework-Tablet, a 3D printable tablet case.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/whatthefilament/Framework-Tablet|title=whatthefilament/Framework-Tablet: 3D Printable Tablet Case for Framework Laptop|via=github.com|author=whatthefilament|access-date=April 30, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://hackaday.com/2022/08/07/build-a-tablet-out-of-your-framework-motherboard/|title=Build A Tablet Out Of Your Framework Motherboard|date=August 7, 2022|website=Hackaday}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pcgamer.com/framework-tablet-build/|title=Modder shows how to transform the Framework laptop into a tablet|date=August 8, 2022|website=PC Gamer}}</ref>
* FrameStation, a modern game console case for the Framework [[motherboard|mainboard]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/whatthefilament/FrameStation|title=whatthefilament/FrameStation: Game Console Case for Framework Motherboard|via=github.com|author=whatthefilament|access-date=May 25, 2022}}</ref>
* Framework Desktop Case Adapter, a 3D printable mount to adapt a Framework [[motherboard|mainboard]] to [[ATX]] and [[MicroATX]] mainboards and cases.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/whatthefilament/Framework-Desktop-Adapter|title=whatthefilament/Framework-Desktop-Adapter: Mounts to adapt Framework motherboard to ATX and Micro-ATX Motherboards and Cases|via=github.com|author=whatthefilament|access-date=June 4, 2022}}</ref>
* Framework Test Bench, a test and development bench for Framework [[motherboard|mainboard]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/whatthefilament/Framework-Test-Bench|title=whatthefilament/Framework-Test-Bench: Test/Development Bench for Framework Motherboard|via=github.com|author=whatthefilament|access-date=June 7, 2022}}</ref>

=== Display ===

* Glider, a 60 [[Frame rate|fps]] [[E-ink]] replacement display.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/zephray_wenting/status/1535041457035280392|title=Wenting on Twitter|first=Wenting|last=Zhang|date=June 10, 2022|via=twitter.com}}</ref>

=== Software ===

* Embedded Controller Modifications, an [[embedded controller|EC]] tool that changes the colors of LEDs and the keyboard layout on the firmware level, plus a suite of tools for talking to and manipulating the EC.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.howett.net/posts/2021-12-framework-ec|title=The Framework Laptop's Embedded Controller (EC)|website=www.howett.net|date=December 22, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_VrFXbRcHs8|title=Framework Holiday Lights|via=www.youtube.com|date=December 26, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=January 23, 2022|url=https://community.frame.work/t/changed-my-keyboard-layout-in-hardware-to-colemak/14174|title=Changed my keyboard layout in hardware to colemak!|website=community.frame.work}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://hackaday.com/2022/06/07/ec-hacking-your-laptop-has-a-microcontroller/|title=EC Hacking: Your Laptop Has A Microcontroller|date=June 7, 2022|first=Arsenijs|last=Picugins|website=Hackaday}}</ref>

=== Others ===

* Framework input cover controller, a [[RP2040]]-based controller for the palmrest, connecting to the keyboard matrix, touchpad, power button, fingerprint sensor [[LED]]s, keyboard backlight and CAPS LOCK [[LED]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/CRImier/MyKiCad/tree/master/Laptop%20mods/framework_input_controller|title=CRImier/MyKiCad: Framework input cover controller|via=github.com|author=CRImier, Ar|access-date=May 16, 2022}}</ref>
* Adjustable laptop stand<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5192872|title=Adjustable Framework Laptop Stand|via=www.thingiverse.com|author=Alexander - I_Mod_Things|access-date=December 28, 2022}}</ref><ref name="frame.work-2022-review" />

== Support ==

{{primary sources|section|date=December 2021}}

The company supports by their [[knowledge base]] articles, community forum, QR codes on the products and parts, and inquiry form.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://frame.work/support|title=Framework Support|website=frame.work}}</ref><ref name="pcmag" /> The company's customer support is controversial. It has both positive reviews that they are transparent, honest, and customer-focused<ref name=elevated-systems-6months-review /><ref name="linus-tech-tips-first-generation-rtc-battery" /> and negative reviews that they close the door.<ref name=linux-after-dark-19>{{Cite web|date=June 10, 2022|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_fNRRiQSw-8&t=1280|title=Linux After Dark – Episode 19|author=Late Night Linux|via=www.youtube.com}}</ref><ref name="twitter-framework-20220610" />

=== Supported countries and regions ===

Framework Laptop is available for order in the US, Canada, The UK, Germany, France, Ireland, The Netherlands and Austria. The company announced they will add additional countries in 2022, introducing their region selection page.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://knowledgebase.frame.work/what-countries-and-regions-do-you-ship-to-r1899ikiO|title=What countries and regions do you ship to?|website=knowledgebase.frame.work}}</ref><ref name="archyde-france">{{Cite web|date=December 17, 2021|url=https://www.archyde.com/framework-the-modular-pc-in-pre-order-for-france/|title=Framework: the modular PC in pre-order for France|website=www.archyde.com}}</ref> In December 2021, the company announced that they chose the additional supported countries UK, Germany and France based on both the number of people who registered interest through the region selection page and on logistical complexity.<ref name="frame.work-pre-order-uk-germany-france" /> In February 2022, pre-ordering became available for Ireland, Austria and The Netherlands.<ref name=":0" /> Pre-orders also opened in Australia in September 2022, with shipments arriving from October.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Buyck|first1=Marissa|title=Now available for pre-order in Australia|url=https://frame.work/au/en/blog/now-available-for-pre-order-in-australia|website=Framework Computers|access-date=2 September 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220902015449/https://frame.work/au/en/blog/now-available-for-pre-order-in-australia|archive-date=2 September 2022|language=en|date=1 September 2022|url-status=live}}</ref>

For people asking to buy Framework Laptop in their region,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://community.frame.work/t/what-countries-will-you-be-shipping-to/181|title=What countries will you be shipping to?|website=community.frame.work}}</ref> the company recommended them wait until the company officially launches in their region before ordering.<ref>{{Cite web|date=May 16, 2021|url=https://community.frame.work/t/ordering-outside-us-using-shipping-forward/1644/2|title=Ordering outside US using shipping forward|website=community.frame.work}}</ref> The company mentioned that if an [[Package forwarding|import service]] was used, they would not be able to support the laptop or warranty.<ref>{{Cite web|date=December 6, 2021|url=https://community.frame.work/t/is-it-a-foolish-endeavor-to-ship-a-laptop-from-the-usa-to-the-netherlands/11854/7|title=Is it a foolish endeavor to ship a laptop from the USA to the Netherlands?|website=community.frame.work}}</ref>

=== Linux ===

In December 2021, the company released a statement asking users who are not using Ubuntu 21.04.3+ or Fedora 35 to troubleshoot with Framework's [[Linux]] community<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://community.frame.work/c/diy-edition/linux/91|title=Linux topics - Framework Community|website=community.frame.work}}</ref> instead of contacting Framework support as no other [[Linux]] distribution has been verified by the company for hardware compatibility, mentioning that the company could troubleshoot general product usage issues on a supported OS, but could not troubleshoot OS related issues not related to the product functionality.<ref>{{Cite web|date=December 17, 2021|url=https://community.frame.work/t/official-linux-and-framework-support-please-read/12435|title=OFFICIAL - Linux and Framework Support - PLEASE READ|website=community.frame.work}}</ref> In April 2022, the company announced their [[Linux]] compatibility page.<ref>{{Cite web|date=|url=https://frame.work/linux|title=Linux on the Framework Laptop|website=frame.work|access-date=June 18, 2022}}</ref><ref name="frame.work-mainboard" />

=== BSD operating systems ===

The company doesn't support [[Berkeley Software Distribution|BSD]] operating systems. In June 2022, the [[FreeBSD Foundation]] announced their work to ensure that the experience running [[FreeBSD]] on the Framework Laptop matches the stability that [[FreeBSD]] users expect.<ref name="freebsd-newsflash">{{Cite web|url=https://www.freebsd.org/news/newsflash/|title=FreeBSD News Flash|website=www.freebsd.org|access-date=June 18, 2022}}</ref><ref name="freebsd-report-2022q1">{{Cite web|date=June 9, 2022|url=https://www.freebsd.org/status/report-2022-01-2022-03/|title=FreeBSD Quarterly Status Report First Quarter 2022|website=www.freebsd.org|access-date=June 18, 2022}}</ref>

=== ChromeOS ===

In September 2022, the company announced the Framework Laptop [[Chromebook]] Edition with the pre-installed [[ChromeOS]] is available for pre-orders.<ref name="framework-chromebook" /><ref name="chromeunboxed-framework-chromebook" /><ref name="zdnet-chromebook" />

== Electronics right to repair movement ==

[[File:Framework Laptop - the Design Museum.jpg|thumb|''Framework Laptop'' as part of the exhibition 'Waste Age: What can design do?' at ''the Design Museum''.]]

In June 2021, a [[venture capitalist]] investing in the company said "The conventional wisdom in the industry is that making products repairable makes them thicker, heavier, uglier, less robust, and more expensive. We’re here to prove that wrong and fix consumer electronics, one category at a time.".<ref name="anorak-post" /> In October 2021, the company said "The core problem is the idea that consumer electronics are disposable.",<ref name="bbc-newshour">{{Cite web|date=October 15, 2021|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p09yt773|title=BBC World Service - Newshour, Could manufacturers help reduce electronic waste?|website=BBC|access-date=June 5, 2022}}</ref> and "Right to repair is incredibly important. It is actually a core part of what we are doing. Because increasingly products are not designed to be repaired." in interviews.<ref name="freethink" />

Framework Laptop was on display as part of the Waste Age: What can Design Do? exhibition<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://designmuseum.org/exhibitions/waste-age-what-can-design-do|title=Waste Age: What can design do? - the Design Museum|website=designmuseum.org|access-date=January 9, 2022}}</ref> displayed at the Design Museum<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://designmuseum.org/|title=Design Museum|website=designmuseum.org|access-date=January 9, 2022}}</ref> in London from October 2021 to February 2022.<ref>{{Cite web|date=January 4, 2022|url=https://www.dailyimportant.thats.im/2022/01/04/framework-develops-modular-laptop-users-can-fix-and-upgrade-themselves/|title=Framework develops modular laptop users can fix and upgrade themselves|website=www.dailyimportant.thats.im|access-date=January 9, 2022}}</ref>
